results.title: For Tomorrow
results.creator_credit: Norman Castle, Lilias Fraser, Conzinc Riotinto of Australia and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: Conzinc Riotinto sends geologists to Bougainville to search for minerals. The rugged mountainous jungle country, heat and humidity makes it an arduous task. They establish a drilling site where much sampling, testing and drilling of the area is carried out to evaluate the location.

results.title: Nimmo St
results.brief_description: This film is a short drama with a musical soundtrack and no dialogue set around Nimmo Street in Middle Park, Melbourne. A young man meets a woman arriving on a ‘Red Rattler’ train and walks her home. On the way, they are accosted by two thugs but manage to avoid conflict. When the young woman reaches her home and doesn’t invite the man in, he leaves and takes out his frustration on the thugs when he encounters them again in the street. A simple, beautifully shot, low budget film capturing Melbourne’s inner suburban street life.

results.title: Apollo 10: around the moon
results.creator_credit: United States. National Aeronautics Space Administration
results.brief_description: The film shows various footage of Apollo 10’s travel around the moon including: the Command module filmed from the Lunar module; the far side of the moon; Command module over landing site No. 2; view from Lunar module sixty miles up; inside the Lunar module; Lunar module descent and much more.

results.title: First Fleet: rite of passage
results.creator_credit: Richard Dennison, Michael Balson, Bill Leimbach, First Fleet Re-enactment Company and Orana Films
results.brief_description: Produced to commemorate Australia’s Bicentenary (1988), this video captures the official First Fleet Reenactment Voyage in 200 minutes of action and adventure. Witness the trials and tribulations of the modern day voyagers who took part in the voyage from Portsmouth on 13 May 1987 to the spectacular finale on Sydney Harbour on Australia Day, 26 January 1988.

results.title: The Hemp revolution
results.creator_credit: Anthony Clarke, Video Vision and Conscious Light
results.brief_description: This documentary proposes that the Hemp plant (Cannabis Sativa Marijuana) could be the solution to several of our major environmental problems. It would meen a shift from the present unsustainable, petrochemical-based economy towards a sustainable plant based economy. A move which could only occur if the drug was legalized. This programme covers the history and varied usage of the plant as well as alternative options in response to the “war on drugs”. Interviews feature Dr Andrew Weil, Dr Lester Grinspoon, Terence McKenna, Dr Kate Short, Professor Peter Dale Scott, Dr Andrew Katelaris and Gatewood Galbraith.

results.title: Amongst equals
results.creator_credit: Paul Hamfess, Tom Zubrycki and Jotz Productions
results.brief_description: Documents the history of the Australian Trade Union Movement. The film is not endorsed by the ACTU and represents only the film maker’s view. The 1850s saw the introduction of the eight hour labour movement and the subsequent development of the trade union movement. Unions were established to organise, assert and defend the worker’s rights, industrial awards, occupational health and safety and minimum wages.

results.title: Tramways
results.creator_credit: Michael Bau, Gunzel and Leonie Dickinson
results.brief_description: A warm hearted look at the people of Melbourne, their trams and their passion. Delves into the fascination with a mode of transport that carries passengers in the 19990’s on 1930’s vehicles.

results.title: The Life of Harry Dare
results.creator_credit: Aleski Vellis, Terry J. Charatsis, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission and Infinity Pictures
results.brief_description: Harry Dare’s troubles began the day he sighted the Kombi van and despite the warnings of ‘Bad Spirit Trouble’, he just had to have it. When the van is stolen, Harry embarks on a journey with his young estranged son Jim to find it. What Harry really discovers is a more meaningful relationship with his son. Stars John Moore as Harry and Aaron Wilton as Jim.

results.title: For today, for tomorrow: new choices for older Australians
results.creator_credit: Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health in association with National Recording Studios Canberra and Maria Taylor
results.brief_description: Through the lives of five older Australians, this program explores the Commonwealth Governments’ new directions for aged care services. The services featured include Home & Community Care services that allow people to remain in their own homes, the Geriatric Assessment Teams that assist individuals and their families in making informed choices and then co-ordinate the services, and a new range of choices for hostels and nursing homes. Discusses programs that address special needs such as those of older migrants. Narrated by June Salter.

results.title: Visions of Victoria
results.creator_credit: Janne Martin Video Productions and Stewart Faichney
results.brief_description:
On a continent distinguished for its unique mixture of climates and for its exotic wildlife, there is no state that provides more variety and contrast than Victoria. Occupying the south-east corner of Australia, and only slightly larger than the size of Great Britain, Victoria has something for everybody. This video takes you on a remarkable tour of the state of Victoria which includes the wilderness areas of its world famous national parks, some of the best surf beaches in the world, Australia’s largest inland lagoon system, a rugged shipwrecked coast, winter resorts and high country, wetlands and even deserts. Also the vibrant and sophisticated city of Melbourne, renowned for its beautiful parks and gardens, exciting restaurants and nightlife, its devotion to the arts and, of course, a fanatical love of sports of all kinds. This superb video is a comprehensive celebration of this wonderful state, in all its beauty, seasons and moods.

Note: the end has a segment on film classification showing Bill Collins introducing the “G” rating.
